newsitem.title: USA: Shareholder sues Texaco over tapes, records.
newsitem.headline: Shareholder sues Texaco over tapes, records.

text.p: A Texaco shareholder on Friday sued officers of the company, including its chairman, over alleged racist remarks and destruction of documents sought in a discrimination suit, the lawyer in the case said.
The lawyer, Joseph Weiss, said he filed the suit in federal court in White Plains, N.Y., where Texaco is based.
The action was taken by shareholder Nathan Kaplan in what is known as a shareholder derivative action on behalf and for the benefit of Texaco.

Earlier this week it was revealed that secret tapes were made of Texaco executives allegedly discussing the destruction of key evidence in a discrimination lawsuit and disparaging minority workers as "niggers" and "black jelly beans."
Excerpts of the tapes were included in court papers seeking sanctions against Texaco as part the discrimination case.

Among defendants named in the shareholder's suit are the men speaking on the tape Robert Ulrich, former treasurer, and Richard Lundwall, former senior coordinator of personnel services in Texaco's finance department.
Texaco Chairman Peter Bijur is also a defendant.
